headline: Trump tariff news: Canada exempt from reciprocal tariffs
context: U.S. President Donald Trump ‚Äúauthorized‚Äù a 90-day pause on some tariffs while vowing to raise levies against China to 125 per cent, effective immediately, he said Wednesday.
It‚Äôs not yet clear how those fees will be applied.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúI have authorized a 90 day PAUSE, and a substantially lowered Reciprocal Tariff during this period, of 10%, also effective immediately,‚Äù the president wrote.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from President Trump about the tariff pause and reduction, which is central to the article's topic.

annotations.paragraph: Trump‚Äôs explosive post sent markets surging, which have been prone to huge swings recently, not just day to day, but hour to hour.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the market reaction to Trump's announcement, which is relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Here are the events of the day:
annotations.reason: This paragraph serves as a transition or introduction to a list and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: Carney says Trump‚Äôs pause on reciprocal tariffs are a ‚Äúwelcome reprieve for the global economy.‚Äù
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a relevant quote from Carney about the impact of Trump's tariff decision.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúAs President Trump and I have agreed, the U.S. President and the Canadian Prime Minister will commence negotiations on a new economic and security relationship immediately following the Federal election,‚Äù Carney wrote on X.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on future negotiations between the U.S. and Canada, which is relevant to the article's focus on tariffs and international relations.

annotations.paragraph: He adds that with this move, the U.S. is willing to engage in bilateral negotiation, ‚Äúwhich will likely result in a fundamental restructuring of the global trading system.‚Äù
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides direct commentary on the potential impact of the tariff decision.

annotations.paragraph: Despite this reprieve, Canada will continue its efforts to strengthen relationships with other trading partners.
annotations.reason: The paragraph offers context on Canada's response to the tariff decision.

annotations.paragraph: Lynn Chaya, breaking news assignment editor
annotations.reason: The paragraph is an attribution line and does not contribute to the story.

annotations.paragraph: The pause on reciprocal tariffs announced by President Trump is a welcome reprieve for the global economy.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a general statement without new information.

annotations.paragraph: As President Trump and I have agreed, the U.S. President and the Canadian Prime Minister will commence negotiations on a new economic and security relationship immediately‚Ä¶
annotations.reason: The paragraph contains a direct quote about future negotiations, relevant to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Asked by a reporter about when he arrived at the decision to pause the tariffs on most countries for 90 days, Trump gave a muddled answer.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Trump's decision-making process regarding the tariff pause.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúFor a period of time. I would say this morning. Over the last few days, I‚Äôve been thinking about it,‚Äù the president said. He added, ‚ÄúFairly early this morning.‚Äù
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into the timing of Trump's decision on the tariff pause.

annotations.paragraph: Earlier in the day, before announcing the pause, Trump on social media urged people to ‚ÄúBE COOL‚Äù and said ‚ÄúTHIS IS A GREAT TIME TO BUY!!!‚Äù
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Trump's public messaging related to the tariff situation.

annotations.paragraph: After members of his administration gave conflicting answers in recent days about whether the tariff hikes were a negotiating ploy, Trump said Wednesday, ‚ÄúA lot of times it‚Äôs not a negotiation until it is.‚Äù
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights the confusion and negotiation strategy surrounding the tariff announcements.

annotations.paragraph: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, who was in the Oval Office with Trump, said the European Union did not face further retaliatory tariffs like China did because the tariffs that the bloc announced Wednesday do not take effect immediately.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about the EU's tariff situation in relation to the U.S. tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad that they held back‚Äù Trump said.
annotations.reason: This quote does not provide new information or context about the tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The Associated Press
annotations.reason: This is a credit line and does not contribute to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: In an email to CTV News Wednesday afternoon, the White House confirmed that Canada is exempt from the 10 per cent baseline reciprocal tariffs it‚Äôs imposing on dozens of other countries.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential information about Canada's exemption from tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Several other U.S. tariffs remain in place, however, including 25 per cent on foreign-made automobiles, of which Canadian vehicles are exempt until U.S. administration ‚Äúestablish(es) a process‚Äù to tax exclusively the non-American vehicle components of Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA)-compliant products.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant details about other tariffs and exemptions related to Canada.

annotations.paragraph: Levies on steel and aluminum ‚Äî which took effect on March 12 ‚Äî are also in place.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about existing tariffs on steel and aluminum.

annotations.paragraph: And 25 per cent tariffs on all Canadian imports and 10 per cent on Canadian energy, which are related to border security, also apply to all non-CUSMA-compliant goods.
annotations.reason: Provides specific details about tariffs on Canadian imports, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Spencer Van Dyk, CTV News Ottawa News Bureau writer & producer. With files from CTV News Ottawa News Bureau supervising producer Stephanie Ha
annotations.reason: This is a credit line and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Stocks surged to one of their biggest gains since World War II after President Donald Trump paused his tariffs against most other nations, as investors had desperately hoped he would. The S&P 500 soared 9.5% Wednesday.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the market reaction to Trump's tariff decision, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The index is still below where it was when Trump announced his sweeping set of tariffs last week.
annotations.reason: Offers additional context on the market's position relative to previous tariff announcements.

annotations.paragraph: The Dow Jones Industrial Average flew nearly 3,000 points higher, and the Nasdaq composite jumped 12.2%.
annotations.reason: Details the market's response to the tariff pause, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The S&P/TSX composite index was up more than five per cent as markets closed, a gain of more than 1,200 points.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides market reaction data, which is not directly related to the main premise about tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The Dow was up almost eight per cent, while the Nasdaq was up more than 12 per cent.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides additional market reaction data, which is not directly related to the main premise about tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Stan Choe, The Associated Press. With files from The Canadian Press
annotations.reason: This is a credit line and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: International Trade Minister Dominic Leblanc has reached out to U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick seeking clarity on Trump‚Äôs latest tariff move.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about diplomatic actions taken in response to the tariff news.

annotations.paragraph: Luca Caruso-Moro, digital breaking news assignment editor
annotations.reason: This is a credit line and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Ernie Tedeschi, former chief economist at the White House Council of Economic Advisors, suggested Trump may have ordered the pause on reciprocal tariffs in part due to the market turmoil seen in the last weeks, and more importantly, the bond market.‚Äú
annotations.reason: Provides expert analysis on possible reasons for the tariff pause.

annotations.paragraph: Equity market turmoil was one thing, but having international investors begin to question the safety value of U.S. treasuries is a whole different level,‚Äù he told CTV News, adding that it‚Äôs the ‚Äúscariest financial data point that we‚Äôve seen since the tariffs began.‚Äù
annotations.reason: Offers specific commentary on financial implications of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: When asked whether he agrees with the Treasury Secretary‚Äôs claim that the pause is not because of the market, Tedeschi says ‚ÄúI just plain don‚Äôt believe that.‚Äù
annotations.reason: Directly addresses a claim about the reasons for the tariff pause.

annotations.paragraph: Lynn Chaya, breaking news assignment editor
annotations.reason: Provides no information relevant to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Trump says he‚Äôs open to tariff carve outs for companies in industries that, ‚Äúby no fault of their own,‚Äù operate in industries that are more reliant on international trade.
annotations.reason: Adds information about potential exceptions to the tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to take a look at that,‚Äù he said, without going into details of which companies could expect such treatment. ‚ÄúYou have to have flexibility.‚Äù
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a direct quote from Trump about the tariff strategy, contributing to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: When asked how he would make those determinations, he said, ‚ÄúJust instinctively.‚Äù
annotations.reason: This quote provides insight into Trump's decision-making process regarding tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúYou almost can‚Äôt take a pencil to paper. It‚Äôs really more of an instinct,‚Äù he said.
annotations.reason: This quote further elaborates on Trump's instinctive approach to tariff decisions.

annotations.paragraph: Luca Caruso-Moro, digital breaking news assignment editor
annotations.reason: This is a byline and does not contribute to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: Equity markets saw significant gains Wednesday afternoon.
annotations.reason: This provides context on the market reaction to the tariff news.

annotations.paragraph: The S&P/TSX Composite Index was trading 4.74 per cent higher at around 23,572.85. In New York, the S&P 500 Index rose around 7.63 per cent to 5,362.71, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 6.41 per cent to 40,057.04 and the Nasdaq Composite Index was up about 9.4 per cent to 16,701.68.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides stock market data unrelated to the main topic of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The TSX financials, information technology and materials subgroups were among the most influential upside contributors.

annotations.paragraph: Daniel Johnson, BNNBloomberg.ca writer
annotations.reason: This is a byline and does not contribute to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúChina wants to make a deal, they just don‚Äôt know how quite to go about it,‚Äù said Trump, addressing reporters during a photo op with race car drivers in Washington, repeating an idea also suggested yesterday by his press secretary ‚Äì that Chinese negotiators aren‚Äôt yet sure how to approach the United States.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a direct quote from Trump relevant to the tariff negotiations with China.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre proud people,‚Äù he said, referring to the Chinese. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll figure it out.‚Äù
annotations.reason: This quote is vague and does not provide new information or context about the tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúMany of you in the media clearly missed the ‚ÄòArt of the Deal,‚Äò‚Äù White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters, in a nod to the Trump‚Äôs 1987 memoir and advice book.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúYou clearly failed to see what President Trump is doing here. You tried to say that the rest of the world would be moved closer to China, when in fact, we‚Äôve seen the opposite effect ‚Äî the entire world is calling the United States of America, not China, because they need our markets,‚Äù she added.
annotations.reason: This quote provides commentary on the global reaction to the tariffs, which is relevant to the article's topic.

annotations.reason: This is a source attribution and does not contribute to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: In a briefing at the White House, U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent clarified that reduced 10 per cent baseline tariffs will remain in place for most countries after U.S. President Donald Trump announced a 90-day pause.

annotations.paragraph: He said the move is being taken because the U.S. has been ‚Äúoverwhelmed with responses from allies who want to negotiate in good faith‚Äù since Trump announced the latest round of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Unifor, the Canadian union representing nearly 22,000 auto workers, publicly endorsed Canada‚Äôs retaliatory tariffs on American vehicles, which come into force today.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúCanada did not start this trade war, but we have no choice but to fight,‚Äù Unifor National President Lana Payne said in a statement on Wednesday.

annotations.paragraph: ‚ÄúWe refuse to back down and sacrifice Canada‚Äôs auto jobs and industry on Donald Trump‚Äôs altar.‚Äù
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes Canada's position and the stakes involved, contributing to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Canada‚Äôs auto tariffs, like the American levies they counter, only affect vehicles that don‚Äôt comply with the countries‚Äô free trade agreement, known as CUSMA.
annotations.reason: This provides important context about the scope and limitations of the tariffs, relevant to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Imported vehicles that are compliant with CUSMA will only face tariffs on content not originating in Canada or Mexico.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about how tariffs will be applied to imported vehicles under CUSMA, which is relevant to the topic of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: CUSMA requires that a certain percentage of the vehicle be made with North American steel and aluminum. It also requires a 75 per cent ‚Äúregional value content,‚Äù meaning that value of the good needs to originate from Canada, the United States, or Mexico.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives detailed context about CUSMA requirements, which is relevant to understanding the tariff exemptions for Canada.

annotations.paragraph: It also includes a labour value content requirement, meaning a significant portion of the value of the vehicle must be produced by a worker earning at least US$16 per hour.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides additional context on CUSMA requirements, which is relevant to the tariff discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Luca Caruso-Moro, digital breaking news assignment editor
annotations.reason: This is a byline and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Delta Air Lines, which believed as recently as January that it was on track for its best financial year in company history, said Wednesday that disruptions in global trade have created such enormous uncertainty that it scratched its performance expectations for 2025.

annotations.paragraph: It is a remarkable walk-back for the United States‚Äô most profitable airline, and other companies are following suit. annotations.paragraph: By declaring a trade war on the rest of the world, U.S. President Donald Trump has panicked global financial markets, raised the risk of a recession and broken the political and economic alliances that made much of the world stable for business after World War II.
